annotation.TEXT: Unfortunately, as Dragon Nezumi's stage is about to demonstrate, there's very few places where you can actually use the Ice Lance's platform functions to its fullest potential (outside of optional or required situations with it). I never really noticed this until now, but most of the stages are designed horizontally with very few vertical-focused challenges in-between.

Dragon Nezumi is arguably one of the toughest bosses in the game, that is, if you don't abuse an exploit that allows you to get behind him. It's not shown here (on account of weapon weaknesses being incredibly potent in this game), but the general idea is to hug the left wall. He won't collide with you if you're pressed up against it all the way, meaning you'll only ever have to react to him when he's on the right side of the room.

Sliding and crouching are the two other major factors of note here: Sliding follows MM6 rules, meaning you can't jump to cancel out of it. Crouching meanwhile is a pretty pointless addition, at least for the most part. There are a few sections where it can actually come in handy, but those are very few and far between (at the very least, it's more helpful than the crouch in MM Rocks).

Well now, here's a game that conjures up a lot of memories. Way back at the end of 2009, I did a single stage-per-segment playthrough of Nezumi Man, making it one of the first MM fan-games to ever appear on my channel. I've wanted to revisit it for a while since then. Given the current situation with YouTube's annotations though, I figured now is the best time to do so (and for those that don't know, there's more info in the description regarding the annotation situation).

On hindsight, I'm kinda glad I went for Ice Nezumi first. Not just because he's relatively easy and his weapon is good, but this is also the only stage in the game to feature ice physics...which is a relief, seeing as they're pretty weird. It feels way too slippery (even by usual ice physic standards), not to mention your momentum carries over slightly into your jump, making it difficult to adjust yourself in mid-air.

Smoke Attack is easily the worst weapon in the game. It fires a few smoke clouds straight up that can randomly spread out (or cluster together). It's highly situational, and even against the one boss that happens to be weak to it, it still has a decent chance of missing.

Dragon Cluster is a strong contender for best weapon in the game. It homes in on things, has a high ammo count, and can generally one or two shot anything besides the larger/tankier enemies. The only drawback is that you can only have one on-screen at a time, which doesn't really negatively impact the weapon that much.

For now though, time for the usual run-down: Aside from graphic and sound aesthetics (and being too adorable for its own good), Nezumi Man's main difference compared to most standard MM games is that you have 26 units in your health/ammo bars instead of 28. This doesn't impact the game that much, but it does become a bit more noticeable if you get in the habit of spamming weapons (some of which are really good).

Ice Lance serves as a decent buster replacement with a good ammo count (its damage is on-par with two normal shots), but it also works as a utility. If it hits a wall, it becomes a makeshift platform you can stand on for a few moments. It also seems to have an 8-shot limit, meaning you can more or less coat entire walls with them.

Wave Nezumi's stage has always been one of my favorites in this game. Sure, it's really easy (then again, the whole game is pretty easy), but the music and gimmicks here have always stuck out to me. The wavy floor mechanic is neat, and unlike the yoku blocks, they actually get a proper introduction (instead of being coupled with spikes like in Ice and Butter Nezumi's stages).

Shock Wave is sadly one of the more unreliable weapons in the game. While it's strong enough to one-shot nearly any minor enemy in the game, it also has a very limited ammo pool (8 shots, to be exact) and incredibly short range. That in itself wouldn't be so bad if not for its rather wonky hitbox that causes it to pass through things completely (this mostly seems to happen if you try using it while jumping).
